JUICIO EN ZARAGOZA
Rodrigo Lanza: "Pensé que iba a morir, solo traté de defenderme"
El acusado de matar a un hombre por una discusión por la bandera de España alega que no pensó que había causado lesiones tan graves a la víctima
04 Nov 2019, 16:00 by L. M. G.
Rodrigo Lanza, el joven de origen chileno acusado de matar a un hombre al que se enfrentó por llevar unos tirantes con la bandera de España, ha declarado este lunes en el juicio por el que se enfrenta a 25 años de prisión. En su comparecencia ante el tribunal, y con un aspecto muy distinto al que llevaba en Barcelona cuando dejó tetrapléjico a un guardia urbano, el activista ha alegado que actuó en defensa propia. "Pensé que iba a morir, solo traté de defenderme", ha aseverado. También ha defendido que su intención fue solo la de "aturdir" a la víctima, no matarlo con sus golpes.   
Lanza se ha emocionado en varias ocasiones durante su relato de los hechos. Ha insistido en que actuó bajo la influencia del alcohol (tres rondas de chupitos, una litrona y tres jarras de cerveza) y por miedo a la navaja (que nunca apareció) que según él llevaba la víctima, Víctor Laínez. "Le di un golpe, cayó al suelo, tuve terror de que se levantara con el cuchillo y le di más golpes". También ha insistido en que no vio los tirantes rojigualdas a Laínez, que vestía una chaqueta negra, informa 'El Periódico de Aragón'.
"Me eché a llorar"
A preguntas solo de su abogado defensor, Endika Zulueta, y del magistrado presidente, José Ruiz Ramo, Lanza ha reconocido que "no pensaba que había causado lesiones graves y mucho menos la muerte". Se enteró del fallecimiento de Laínez en los calabozos del Cuerpo Nacional de Policía. "En ese momento me eché a llorar", ha asegurado, mientras se emocionaba.
Lanza ha relatado que aquella noche iba con un amigo y dos amigas de este. Los cuatro accedieron al bar El Tocadiscos por la noche, donde estaba Laínez. "Pedí un cubata, no me acuerdo quién lo hizo porque estaba tocado y Pablo me comentó que el hombre de la barra era un conocido fascista del barrio; yo me quedé extrañado e incómodo, pero no le di más importancia. [Sin embargo] el hombre me miró, hizo un gesto con la cabeza y yo fui a hablar con él, lo hice como para hacerme el chulo con las chicas, una niñatada, pero no hubo ni amenazas aunque fue una conversación tensa", ha dicho.
"Tuve terror de que me atacara con un cuchillo y le di más golpes"
Rodrigo Lanza
Acusado de asesinato
Tras ese primer encuentro, según Lanza, él regresó a la zona en la que estaba con los amigos para decirles lo que había pasado y se lo recriminaron. "Una de las chicas dijo que desde que me había acercado, él no paro de usar el móvil, nos entró paranoia de ‘a ver si viene alguien y dije vámonos de aquí’, me acojoné", ha afirmado.
Ya había abierto la puerta para que pasaran las chicas cuando su amigo Pablo, tal y como ha recordado, le gritó: "Cuidado, lleva una navaja"; "en ese momento Laínez se acercó a mí, así que le di una patada como para alejarlo, le empujé en el torso". "El hombre vino hacia mí, entré en las puertas y entré en pánico", ha apostillado.
"Pensé que me iba a matar entre las dos puertas y le intenté alejar a patadas, en una fuerte lo alejé y ya no me acuerdo de nada", ha recalcado, a la vez que ha añadido que le dio un golpe que le hizo caer al suelo. "Tuve terror de que se levantara con el cuchillo y le di golpes", ha incidido.
"Siento su dolor"
Su declaración ha finalizado diciendo que actuó porque se le atacó. "Yo no sé qué decirles a los familiares, siento su dolor, pero yo solo traté de defenderme".
Mañana continuará el juicio contra Lanza, quien ha cambiado radicalmente su imagen. Atrás quedaron las rastas, los piercing y la ropa de estética antisistema y hoy se ha presentado ante el jurado popular con camisa azul, pantalón beige, zapatos marrones y abrigo del mismo tono.

JUDGMENT IN ZARAGOZA
Rodrigo Lanza: "I thought I was going to die, I just tried to defend myself"
The accused of killing a man for an argument over the flag of Spain alleges that he did not think he had caused such serious injuries to the victim
04 Nov 2019, 16:00 by L. M. G.
Rodrigo Lanza, the young man of Chilean origin accused of killing a man he faced for wearing suspenders with the flag of Spain, said Monday in the trial for which he faces 25 years in prison. In his appearance before the court, and with a very different aspect to the one he wore in Barcelona when he left an urban guard quadriplegic, the activist has alleged that he acted in self-defense. "I thought I was going to die, I just tried to defend myself," he said. He has also defended that his intention was only to "stun" the victim, not to kill him with his blows.
Lanza has been moved several times during his story of events. He has insisted that he acted under the influence of alcohol (three rounds of shots, a litrona and three jugs of beer) and for fear of the razor (which never appeared) that according to him the victim was carrying, Víctor Laínez. "I hit him, he fell to the ground, I was terrified that he would get up with the knife and hit him more." He has also insisted that he did not see the rojigualdas suspenders to Laínez, who wore a black jacket, reports 'El Periódico de Aragón'.
"I started to cry"
To questions only from his defense lawyer, Endika Zulueta, and the presiding magistrate, José Ruiz Ramo, Lanza has acknowledged that "he did not think that he had caused serious injuries and much less death." He learned of Laínez's death in the dungeons of the National Police Corps. "At that moment I started to cry," he said, while getting excited.
Lanza has said that he was going with a friend and two friends of this night. The four accessed the record player bar at night, where Lainez was. "I asked for a cubata, I don't remember who did it because he was touched and Pablo told me that the man at the bar was a well-known fascist in the neighborhood; I was surprised and uncomfortable, but I didn't give it more importance. [However] he man looked at me, nodded and I went to talk to him, I did it to make a pimp with the girls, a girl, but there were no threats even though it was a tense conversation, "he said.
"I was terrified that he would attack me with a knife and hit him more"
Rodrigo Lanza
Accused of murder
After that first meeting, according to Lanza, he returned to the area where he was with friends to tell them what had happened and they recriminated him. "One of the girls said that since he had approached me, he did not stop using his cell phone, we were paranoia of‘ to see if anyone is coming and I said let's get out of here, "I said," he said.
He had already opened the door for the girls to pass when his friend Pablo, as he recalled, shouted: "Be careful, carry a knife"; "At that moment Laínez approached me, so I kicked him away, I pushed him in the torso." "The man came to me, I entered the doors and panicked," he added.
"I thought he was going to kill me between the two doors and I tried to kick him away, in a strong I moved him away and I don't remember anything anymore," he stressed, while adding that he hit him down. "I was terrified that he would get up with the knife and hit him," he said.
"I feel your pain"
His statement has ended by saying that he acted because he was attacked. "I don't know what to tell family members, I feel their pain, but I just tried to defend myself."
Tomorrow will continue the trial against Lanza, who has radically changed his image. Gone are the dreadlocks, piercing and anti-system aesthetic clothing and today he has appeared before the popular jury with blue shirt, beige pants, brown shoes and coat of the same tone.
